channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pranks, Parties and Politics: Ron DeSantis’s Year as a Schoolteacher
item.description: At a private school 20 years ago, the future Florida governor was a popular history teacher and coach. But some students were taken aback by his comments on the Civil War and abortion.
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ron DeSantis taught at Darlington School, a private boarding school in Rome, Ga., in the 2001-02 school year, after graduating from Yale University and just before attending Harvard Law School.

item.title: Democrats Ushered In the Los Angeles Sheriff. Now Many Want Him Gone.
item.description: Alex Villanueva’s combative approach has antagonized many officials and spurred an extraordinary ballot measure that would allow county leaders to oust him.
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheriff Alex Villanueva campaigning with volunteers door-to-door in Carson, Calif., last month in his bid for re-election.

item.title: Miami-Dade County Was Once a Lock for Democrats. Not Anymore.
item.description: Republicans could flip Florida’s most populous county, a “massive warning sign” for Democratic Party leaders.
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Republicans win in Miami-Dade County, the era of Florida’s status as a purple swing state will likely come to an end.

item.title: Between Kanye and the Midterms, the Unsettling Stream of Antisemitism
item.description: For American Jews, this fall has become increasingly worrisome. On Thursday alone, the F.B.I. warned of threats to New Jersey synagogues and the Nets suspended Kyrie Irving.
item.media:credit: Ted Shaffrey/Associated Press
item.media:description: Police stand outside Temple Beth-El synagogue in Jersey City, N.J., on Thursday. The FBI said it had received credible information about a “broad” threat to synagogues in the state.

item.title: Fetterman Makes Reference to a Steelers Legend in Resurfaced Ad
item.description: Puzzled responses on Twitter to an homage to “Mean” Joe Greene offered Fetterman supporters a chance to mock Dr. Mehmet Oz, his Republican opponent in the Pennsylvania Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: LaRita Wilson, 65, next to John Fetterman’s merchandise truck outside a senior center in Upper Darby, Pa., on Friday.

item.title: Astronomers Find a Black Hole in Our Cosmic Back Yard
item.description: Just 1,600 light-years away, the black hole is the closest known to Earth. The good news: It’s dormant, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.category: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Journal)
item.media:credit: International Gemini Observatory/NOIRLab/NSF/AURA
item.media:description: An artist’s impression of the black hole and its companion star, a mere 1,600 light-years away from Earth.

item.title: $1.6 Billion Powerball Jackpot Sets Off Ticket-Buying Frenzy
item.description: The odds of getting the winning numbers are 1 in 292.2 million, but that did not dash the hopes of players ahead of the drawing on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Julio Cortez/Associated Press
item.media:description: The estimated $1.6 billion Powerball jackpot is the largest in U.S. history.

item.title: Medicare Advantage or Just Medicare?
item.description: It’s annual enrollment season once again. Here’s a look at the pros and cons of the two approaches to health insurance.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The proportion of eligible Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in Medicare Advantage plans will exceed 50 percent next year, experts estimate.

item.title: Time Warp
item.description: How readers are adjusting to the end of daylight saving time.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Republican Gains in Congress Would Pressure Biden on Ukraine and Iran
item.description: Officials in the Biden administration expect plenty of complications, including summons to hearings over the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy said last month that a Republican-led House would be unwilling to approve “blank check” assistance for Ukraine.

item.title: Trump, Biden and Obama Will Campaign in Pennsylvania in Midterm Finale
item.description: As the midterms come to a close, the establishment politics of the two most recent Democratic presidents will meet the disruptive force of the last Republican one, with control of Congress at stake.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump will rally Republicans on Saturday in southwest Pennsylvania, while President Biden and former President Barack Obama will speak to Democrats in Philadelphia.

item.title: Ahead of the Midterms, Family Ties Are Strained by Political Divisions
item.description: For Carolyn Broe and her family, the 2022 midterms have unfolded the way they have for countless others: with great bitterness and turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carolyn Broe, a Republican, lives in Scottsdale, Ariz., with her husband, a Libertarian, and their two adult children, who are to the left of the Democratic Party.

item.title: For These New York Farmers, Harvest Time Means High Times
item.description: In fields from Sag Harbor to Ithaca, a new crop ripened this fall: cannabis plants grown for recreational marijuana.
item.dc:creator: John Ortved and Paul Barbera
item.media:credit: Paul Barbera for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the 1930s, the growing of cannabis was all but banned across the United States.

item.title: Fed Up With Political Text Messages? Read On.
item.description: In this polarized climate, hundreds of Americans told us they agree on one thing: Campaigns must stop spamming voters’ phones with unwanted political texts.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: Oz to Rally With Trump in Pennsylvania on Saturday
item.description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s support pulled Dr. Mehmet Oz across the finish line in the Republican primary, but Dr. Oz has kept Mr. Trump largely at arm’s length in the general election.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: In recent appearances, Dr. Mehmet Oz, Pennsylvania’s Republican Senate nominee, has barely uttered the name “Trump.”

item.title: Biden and Obama Reunite in a Last-Ditch Effort to Save Their Party
item.description: A rally on Saturday in Philadelphia will be their first joint campaign appearance since President Biden took office, adding a twist to the relationship of what has always been a political odd couple.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with former President Barack Obama. It comes as a bit of a bittersweet reality for Mr. Biden to have to depend on Mr. Obama, whose shadow he has sought to escape for years.

item.title: ‘Cold and Tense’: 10 Americans on How Politics Changes Relationships
item.description: Ten readers share their stories about the strain today’s politics has put on their family and personal relationships.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Audrey Vera of Oakland, Calif., fell out with her band after telling them she was dating a police officer.

item.title: Michigan G.O.P. Candidates Show Unity as Midterm Campaigns Enter Homestretch
item.description: Candidates for governor, secretary of state and attorney general join forces to get out the vote.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tudor Dixon, the Republican candidate for governor, at a rally in Davison, Mich., on Friday.

item.title: Jan. 6 Committee Gives Trump More Time to Comply With Subpoena
item.description: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack said it was in discussions with the former president over his compliance ahead of an interview scheduled for this month.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representatives Liz Cheney and Bennie Thompson, the leaders of the House Jan. 6 committee, at the end of a June hearing.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi Says Her Husband’s Recovery Will Be a ‘Long Haul’
item.description: In her first publicly broadcast comments since her husband was injured by a hammer-wielding attacker, Ms. Pelosi said that “we have to be optimistic.”
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi outside her home in San Francisco on Friday.

item.title: What Happened on Georgia’s Last Day of Early Voting
item.description: A Democratic former congressman gave his support to the incumbent Republican governor.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times

item.title: What Twitter’s Shake-Up Could Mean: Midterm Misinformation Run Amok
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ballots in Bucks County, Pa., were stored after being recorded last month. Election conspiracy theories have flourished in Pennsylvania since the 2020 presidential contest.

item.title: Democrats Promote Tough-on-Crime Credentials as Party Plays Defense
item.description: With sheriffs vouching for them and a flood of ads proclaiming their support for the police, Democrats are shoring up their public safety bona fides. Still, some worry it’s too late.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat of Nevada in a highly competitive race for re-election, has long highlighted her pro-law enforcement credentials.

item.title: Moderate House Democrats Are at Risk, Putting the Majority Up for Grabs
item.description: Several Democrats elected in 2018 with an anti-Trump message in conservative-leaning districts are centering their closing argument on protecting democracy as they try to buck national trends.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Kristen Zeis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Redistricting has shifted Representative Elaine Luria’s Virginia district to the right, and voters appear likely to rebel against President Biden.

item.title: Most Candidates Running on Crime Don’t Have Much Power to Solve It
item.description: Your congressman doesn’t control the police budget. Your senator probably doesn’t know where the worst hot spots are.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger
item.media:credit: Ian Maule/Tulsa World, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A police investigation of a possible murder-suicide that left eight people dead near Tulsa last week. Oklahoma has higher violent crime rates than California.

item.title: Florida Restricts Doctors From Providing Gender Treatments to Minors
item.description: The state’s medical board, whose members are appointed by the governor, has barred doctors from prescribing gender care to new adolescent patients.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.media:credit: Lizzie Heintz/Orlando Sentinel/Sipa USA/Alamy Live News
item.media:description: A rally in support of transgender young people outside Orlando City Hall in June 2021.

item.title: Oath Keepers Leader Testifies at Jan. 6 Sedition Trial
item.description: Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the far-right militia group, took the stand in his own defense in Federal District Court in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Jim Urquhart/Reuters
item.media:description: Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers militia, in 2016. He sought to defend himself against sedition charges when he took the witness stand on Friday.

item.title: In a First, US Pays Tribes to Move Away From Climate Threats
item.description: The Interior Department has selected the winners of a new competition to relocate communities vulnerable to climate change. It could become a model for the rest of the country.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mary Tunuchuk, a resident of Chefornak, Alaska, since the 1950s, where melting permafrost is causing homes to sink. Cherfornak, which received $3 million, was one of three Alaskan communities given grants to move.

item.title: GOP Lawmakers Question Amtrak Over Six-Figure Bonuses
item.description: Two Republicans on the House Transportation Committee asked the rail service to explain how it awards bonuses after top executives received payouts of more than $200,000 each last year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: The lawmakers’ letter was sent after a report by The New York Times revealed that Amtrak paid out $2.3 million in short-term incentive bonuses to top executives despite reporting its lowest revenue and biggest losses in more than a decade.

item.title: What to Know About the Danny Masterson Rape Trial
item.description: The “That ’70s Show” actor has been charged with raping three women in the early 2000s. Two of the women have said the Church of Scientology discouraged them from reporting the assaults to the police.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Anna Webber/Getty Images
item.media:description: Masterson in 2017.

item.title: House Candidate Drops Ad in North Carolina After Report of Bullet Hole
item.description: After news belatedly broke that a Republican congressional candidate’s parents had found a bullet hole at their home, the Democrat in the race pulled an ad showing a different residence belonging to his opponent.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A photo provided by the campaign of Pat Harrigan, a Republican running for an open House seat in North Carolina, shows a bullet hole in a window in the laundry room of his parents’ home.

item.title: Both Parties Seek Advantage in Last Jobs Report Before Midterms
item.description: Republicans seized on a slight uptick in the unemployment rate as they focused their closing message on the economy. Democrats defended ‘steady, sustainable’ job growth and warned that G.O.P. victories would risk backsliding.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden used the jobs report on Friday to tout the strength of the economy, while Republican campaign messaging seized on the increase in the unemployment rate as a line of attack ahead of Tuesday’s elections.

item.title: Biden Spins His Economic Record Ahead of Elections
item.description: The president’s recent comments on Social Security, the deficit and economic growth claim credit where it is not always due.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: White House officials have sometimes been forced to awkwardly correct President Biden’s claims. Other times, they have doubled down on them.
